Award.AwardTitle: Conference Funding Proposal: Advances in Cryptology - CRYPTO 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports 20 students for their travel to attend the 2016 Annual International Cryptology Conference (CRYPTO), sponsored by IACR (International Association of Cryptologic Research), in cooperation with the Computer Science Department of the University of California, Santa Barbara. CRYPTO is a highly selective conference in cryptography, attracting students, researchers and industry specialists from all over the world. The scope of research papers accepted to CRYPTO range from the theoretical foundations of cryptology to application and implementation of cryptographic schemes. As such, it fits closely with the goals of NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which include applied cryptography and implementation of cryptographic schemes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advances in Cryptology -- Crypto is a premier venue for the latest academic research in cryptography and is held each summer at the University of California, Santa Barbara.  It is organized by the International Association for Cryptologic Research (IACR), the main professional organization for cryptography research.  Crypto is one of three “flagship” IACR General Conferences (along with Eurocrypt and Asiacrypt) whose purpose is to provide a forum for presentation and discussion of the latest research results in the field.  Additionally, every three years the IACR’s Area Conference on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) is co-located with Crypto to provide additional opportunities for these two communities to interact.  2016 was a co-location year for Crypto and CHES and there were combined sessions and meals for the two conferences during their overlap period. 

This year was the 36th year of the Crypto conference, and we had over 450 attendees with 27 countries represented.  In total, there were 70 papers presented at Crypto in two parallel tracks across a wide variety of topics in cryptography including asymmetric and symmetric cryptography, hash functions, cryptanalysis, obfuscation, multiparty computation, algorithmic number theory, lattice-based cryptography, zero-knowledge protocols, functional encryption, and more.  

This NSF Award helped enable US-based students and US citizens studying overseas to attend the Crypto 2016 conference.  Attendance at top-tier conferences such as Crypto is crucial for the training and development of students in the field. They benefit not only by giving or attending talks, but also from the many opportunities to meet junior and senior researchers, discuss their work, and spark new collaborations to solve the many challenging open problems in the field of cryptography.  The availability of funding support was advertised widely, and generous sponsorship by NSF and Microsoft Research allowed us to extend some form of support for all students who requested it. In total, 15 students received support from the NSF for attendance in the form of registration and lodging waivers and, in some cases, air and/or ground travel reimbursements.
